connectionForm.nonBreakingChangesPrefere: When the source schema changes, I want to:
Automatically reflect source schema changes in your destination. Propagating all changes will incur costs for new streams.
Propagate all field and stream changes
Schema changes will be detected, but not propagated. Syncs will continue running with the schema you've set up, if possible.
Connections will be automatically disabled as soon as any schema changes are detected.
Only column changes will be propagated. Incompatible schema changes (type changes, deletions) will be detected, but not propagated.
All new tables and column changes from the source (additions and deletions) are automatically synced to the destination.
Determine how Airbyte handles <lnk>schema changes</lnk> from the source.
Auto-propagation will start with your next scheduled sync. To apply immediately, run a manual sync after saving the connection.

This option is recommended for analytics use cases or where downstream reporting depends on historical data.
connection.actions.refreshStream.truncat: Refresh {value, plural, one {stream} other {streams}} and remove records

By electing to refresh your {value, plural, one {stream} other {streams}} and <bold>remove records</bold>, you are instructing Airbyte to remove previously synced records that are no longer in the source. This option is recommended for database replication use cases where you expect a 1:1 mirror of the source. Use this option carefully as this is not reversible.

connectorBuilder.incremental.formatPlace:
Use placeholders starting with "%" to describe the format the API is using. The following placeholders are available:
* **%s**: Epoch unix timestamp - `1686218963`
* **%a**: Weekday (abbreviated) - `Sun`
* **%A**: Weekday (full) - `Sunday`
* **%w**: Weekday (decimal) - `0` (Sunday), `6` (Saturday)
* **%d**: Day of the month (zero-padded) - `01`, `02`, …, `31`
* **%b**: Month (abbreviated) - `Jan`
* **%B**: Month (full) - `January`
* **%m**: Month (zero-padded) - `01`, `02`, …, `12`
* **%y**: Year (without century, zero-padded) - `00`, `01`, …, `99`
* **%Y**: Year (with century) - `0001`, `0002`, …, `9999`
* **%H**: Hour (24-hour, zero-padded) - `00`, `01`, …, `23`
* **%I**: Hour (12-hour, zero-padded) - `01`, `02`, …, `12`
* **%p**: AM/PM indicator
* **%M**: Minute (zero-padded) - `00`, `01`, …, `59`
* **%S**: Second (zero-padded) - `00`, `01`, …, `59`
* **%f**: Microsecond (zero-padded to 6 digits) - `000000`
* **%z**: UTC offset - `(empty)`, `+0000`, `-04:00`
* **%Z**: Time zone name - `(empty)`, `UTC`, `GMT`
* **%j**: Day of the year (zero-padded) - `001`, `002`, …, `366`
* **%U**: Week number of the year (starting Sunday) - `00`, …, `53`
* **%W**: Week number of the year (starting Monday) - `00`, …, `53`
* **%c**: Date and time - `Tue Aug 16 21:30:00 1988`
* **%x**: Date standard format - `08/16/1988`
* **%X**: Time standard format - `21:30:00`
* **%%**: Literal '%' character

Some placeholders depend on the locale of the underlying system - in most cases this locale is configured as en/US. For more information see the [Python documentation](https://docs.python.org/3/library/datetime.html#strftime-and-strptime-format-codes).

connectorBuilder.incremental.label: Incremental Sync
connectorBuilder.incremental.tooltip: Configure how to fetch data incrementally based on a time field in your data
The capabilities of the API to filter data based on the cursor field
The API can filter data based on a range (start and end datetime) of the cursor field.
The API can filter data based on the start datetime, but will always include all data from the start date up to now.
The API can't filter by the cursor field. When choosing this option, make sure the data is ordered descending on the cursor field (newest to oldest).

The data must be returned in descending order for the cursor field across pages in order for incremental sync to work properly with no time filtering. If the data is returned in ascending order, you should not configure incremental syncs for this API.

connectorBuilder.incremental.userInput.e: The time up to which to sync as a user input. Fill it in in the testing values
connectorBuilder.incremental.custom.valu: The earliest time to cutoff the sync
The time up to which to sync
connectorBuilder.incremental.custom.form: The format of the provided start datetime. If not specified, the format of the cursor value is used.
The format of the provided earliest datetime cutoff. If not specified, the format of the cursor value is used.
The format of the provided end date. If not specified, the format of the cursor value is used.
connectorBuilder.incremental.startTimeIn: Inject Start Time into outgoing HTTP Request
Optionally configures how the start datetime will be sent in requests to the source API
connectorBuilder.incremental.endTimeInje: Inject End Time into outgoing HTTP Request
Optionally configures how the end datetime will be sent in requests to the source API
connectorBuilder.incremental.outgoingDat: The datetime format used to format the datetime values that are sent in outgoing requests to the API. If not provided, the first format in Cursor Datetime Formats will be used.
connectorBuilder.incremental.splitUpInte: Optionally split up the interval into smaller chunks to reduce the amount of data fetched in a single request and to make the sync more resilient to failures
connectorBuilder.incremental.cursorDatet: The possible formats for the cursor field, in order of preference. The first format that matches the cursor field value will be used to parse it.

connectorBuilder.parentStreams.label: Parent Stream
connectorBuilder.parentStreams.tooltip: Configure another stream to be the parent of this stream. This means that for each record in the parent stream, a separate request will be made for the current stream with the parent record's data accessible for injection or interpolation.
connectorBuilder.parentStreams.parentStr: The stream to read records from. Make sure there are no cyclic dependencies between streams

The identifier that should be used for referencing the parent key value in interpolation. For example, if this field is set to `parent_id`, then the parent key value can be referenced in interpolation as `'{{' stream_partition.parent_id '}}'`
Inject Parent Key into outgoing HTTP Request
Optionally configures how the parent key will be sent in requests to the source API

Causes the parent stream's records to be read incrementally, so only parent records that have been updated since the last sync will be retrieved for use in this stream.

**This only works if this child stream is Incremental.**

**WARNING:** If the parent stream records' cursor fields are NOT updated whenever the relevant child records are updated, then those child records may be missed!
